awd_titl_txt: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH:  Evaluating Calcification on a Hawaiian Coral Reef Using a Novel, Solid-State Total Alkalinity and pH Sensor
awd_abstract_narration:
Changing environmental conditions, including ocean warming and ocean acidification, are having a profound impact on the chemistry of the ocean and on marine ecosystems, particularly coral reefs. Net Ecosystem Calcification (NEC) rate is a strong indicator of stress in coral reef systems, but the lack of sensors that can make autonomous measurements at appropriate time and space scales has limited the scientific community's ability to fully examine the factors that drive NEC changes in coral reef environments. This project addresses the sensor limitation by furthering the development of a novel technology that can measure both total alkalinity and pH every 60 seconds. The solid-state sensor design does not rely on chemical reagents that need to be replaced or pollute the environment. The utility of this novel sensor will be proven in Kaneohe Bay Hawaii, one of the most well instrumented and studied coral reef ecosystems in the world. The successful completion of this project will not only improve our understanding of the drivers of NEC variability, but will also provide the community with a new ocean acidification sensor package that could be used to characterize the ocean carbon system under a wide variety of circumstances. The improvements and documentation produced on how to build these sensors will take the community one step closer to having a commercially viable system that could be transitioned to industry. This work will help inform Hawaiian managers as well as those from other Pacific Islands with substantial coral reef structures on how to evaluate the health and growth of their reef systems. This project will also help train the next generation of ocean scientists through support of a postdoctoral associate and graduate student who will learn to apply the sensor to field measurements and ocean carbon research. 


The solid-state, reagentless sensor package is based on an ISFET coulometric diffusion titration. The investigators propose to build four systems to test key calcification hypotheses that can best be addressed with these new sensors. They will deploy one stationary sensor on a mooring inside Kaneohe Bay Hawaii, in close proximity to an actively growing coral reef, and one stationary sensor on a mooring outside of Kaneohe Bay that is largely representative of the waters entering the reef system. Two additional sensor packages will be mounted in a low profile surface drifter for Lagrangian studies over the reef flat between the moorings. These sensors will provide measurements of seawater carbon chemistry at a resolution and precision not previously possible. The simultaneous characterization of waters entering the reef and leaving the reef will allow the investigators to study the drivers of reef calcification over a wide range of time-scales from minutes to seasons.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goals of this project were to fabricate and test autonomous pH-alkalinity sensor packages based on a design originally developed at Scripps Institution of Oceanography. Sensors were to be deployed on moorings in Kaneohe Bay, HI to collect timeseries measurements of pH and total alkalinity (TA) and sensors were to be integrated into drifters and used to evaluate bulk rates of metabolism and calcification across a heterogenous reef structure.

Initial progress on this project was hampered by the global pandemic that shut down labs at UH and Scripps. After the COVID-19 travel restrictions were finally eased, co-PI Ellen Briggs traveled to San Diego in May 2021 and completed the proposed Ion-Sensitive Field-Effect Transistor (ISFET) chip modifications, a key component of the new sensor, with specialized equipment at the UCSD. Unfortunately, the sensors produced at the UCSD nano3 facility were shown to have a compromised electrode surface due to a contamination problem in the cleanroom.  We were working on solutions to this issue when, to the surprise of the oceanographic community, Honeywell halted manufacturing of the ISFET chip required to build our sensor. Briggs located a promising alternative ISFET manufacturer (LioniX), but pursuing this would require a fundamental reworking of sensor design.  Because this re-scoping of the sensor was not in the original budget, the knowledge learned through confronting these challenges, including issues associated with electrode deposition and ISFET redesign were openly communicated to the company Aquatic Labs, where work is ongoing to redesign the sensor based on lessons learned and design concepts developed through this award.  We hope that Aquatic Labs will soon produce a commercially available sensor for the oceanographic community.   The autonomous sensor packages produced by SIO through this project will be ready to test the new sensor when it is available.

Despite the initial intent to include a TA sensor for comprehensive net ecosystem metabolism characterization, the team decided to advance with drifter testing without the TA sensor. The drifter prototype is designed to measure key environmental variables, including pH, oxygen, temperature, and salinity. Additionally, the drifter is equipped with a camera and GPS system, enabling the documentation of changes in benthic communities over the course of the drift track. To supplement the understanding of TA gradients in the area, discrete TA measurements are taken along the transects. Preliminary findings from drifter deployments have uncovered noteworthy pH (H+) fluctuations of +/-5% acidity, while discrete measurements of TA indicate variations of +/-9 umol kg-1 when there was a transition from a coral patch to a sandy environment. The major accomplishment is that the high-frequency pH measurements with the drifter were capable of capturing small changes between benthic composition, which can suggest complex biogeochemical processes recorded in the water chemistry that could be influenced by various factors, including biological activity, water flow, and the composition of the seabed. The capacity of the drifter deployments to capture high-frequency pH measurements that reveal small but significant fluctuations between different benthic compositions marks a significant advancement in our ability to monitor and understand the intricate biogeochemical processes of marine environments. Our next steps include expanding the deployment of drifters to cover a broader range of environments and conditions to build a more comprehensive understanding of pH variability across different marine ecosystems.
